issue.title: verify_local_bear: Add base directory argument
issue.body:
Some linters expect to have some additional files in the base directory where it is invoked.
verify_local_bear needs an optional argument to supply this directory, and then change into that directory while running the bear.
coala_utils 's ContextManagers.change_directory may be useful for this.

issue.title: Support Python 3.4.x
issue.body:
Python 3.4.0-3 were dropped because of 8a08cd2, due to Python <3.4.4 not having asyncio.run_coroutine_threadsafe.  This has only happened in the current dev release.
However package trollius provides that on Python 2.7+
Python 3.4.3 is used as the Trusty default, so supporting it has benefit to users and especially to CI which uses that by default for all non-Python languages.
It also means the platform requirements of 0.11 will continue to be supported by the next release.

issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.title: Running Coala when a PR is created
issue.body:
Hello,
I'm currently using Coala manually but I think it could be a nice improvement if Coala could be run when a PR is sent to a repository.
With Julia language, there is a nice Github bot called FemtoCleaner which is able to fix automatically depreciation warnings and send PR automatically to Github repositories where this bot is installed.
A similar feature for Python and linting / fixing code with Coala could be a nice improvement.
I also wonder if Github Actions https://github.com/features/actions https://www.techworm.net/programming/github-actions-workflow-automating-tool/  couldn't also be used (when available) to provide a nice workflow for linting / fixing code with Coala.
Kind regards

issue.title: Make the README a kinder place by removing/replacing the John Woods quote
issue.body:
This is migrated from #5767
As @joenash suggests,
Hey folks ðŸ‘‹

This PR is to discuss the removal of the John Woods quote from the README. I believe that quote is a product of its time (1991), and that Coala can do better to be a welcoming project.
We should write maintainable code because we have respect for our peers and colleagues who will read and work with it, not because of threat of death. The quote is also unnecessarily gendered.

Apologies also for the drive-by PR ðŸ™‡ For some additional context, I became aware of this quote because I work with a lot of software development students, and saw a large number were contributors to Coala. Coala is doing an amazing job of being accessible to students and upcoming software developers, but this also makes it important to ensure that students who work on this project are being taught respect for their fellow humans ðŸ’–

I've added [WIP] as currently this commit removes the quote entirely. It may be more suitable to find an alternative to fill that space and act as the one-line pitch. If anyone has suggestions, please feel free to add them!

Some follow-up discussions can be found on that PR. This issue is opened as the pull request is not a correct place to discuss/vote.

issue.title: Glob.fnmatch logic inverted breaking backwards compatibility
issue.body: PR #5259 for issue #2302 broke coala-quickstart .

issue.title: FileDict and FileProxy fixes
issue.body:
fbe8452 introduced FileDict, as a subclass of dict.
It contains many unnecessary methods which needlessly override the dict method.  The override methods mostly just call the super() method, creating an extra performance degradation.
The only method which isnt just super() is __getitem__.  It contains a bug, because if the value in the dict has 0 lines, val is [] , and if val: will be false, and None is returned instead of [].  That is wildly different behaviour to previously, as None is not iterable.  It means all code (including global bears) needs to check whether the file is None before iterating over the file contents.  File contents being None was previously possible, but only when 'raw' mode was enabled.  A file with 0 lines is not the same as an unreadable / raw file.
FileFactory was introduced in b06dfe4.  The most critical problem is that it is not a "factory".  Factories are an extremely important and very well established pattern covered in all OO books with buying ( https://www.oodesign.com/factory-pattern.html ), so to call this a factory is very confusing / misleading.
It was to be a wrapper for a "file" object, which was previously a list of str, where each item was a line of the file.  While a design goal was to hide some of the details, it still needs to be backwards compatible in order to avoid breaking existing code.  This is especially important at the moment given that the current status of coala is so bug ridden with many regressions that investigating bugs requires installing from old git commits more than a year to verify the old behaviour.
Two "list" unimplemented methods which were used by coala-quickstart are __len__ and __getitem__.  These missing methods need to be re-implemented.  If there is a good justification for deprecating them, that deprecation should be done properly.  For __len__, it seems unjustifiable to not provide this, as this single number can be cached and provides a lot of information, and is especially helpful if avoiding re-reading files which have been evicted from the cache, as a 0 line file can be more efficiently created in memory than re-reading from the disk.  __getitem__ is much easier to justify deprecating if the file contents are being evicted from the cache to reduce the memory footprint of coala.  That hasnt been implemented yet.

issue.title: LocalBearTestHelper: Proper deprecation for timeout
issue.body:
#5723 was an over-hasty way of removing the dependency on pytest.
The assert not timeout broke one of the bears which used the timeout.
The bear was updated to remove the unnecessary timeout, but the assert will break old versions of coala-bears being used with the current coalib, which needlessly complicates setting up an environment to investigate old bugs.
It should be properly deprecated with a warning that the timeout is ignored.

issue.title: process_output_corrected should not treat \n as reason to empty a file
issue.body:
If there is an error on stderr, usually stdout is \n.
process_output_corrected should not interpret \n as intended to be the corrected file being an empty file.  It should emit an INFO message to say \n was ignored.
Possibly an extra flag might be added to allow \n to really mean an empty file, if there is no way that the linter ever has an empty file except when it is recommending an empty file (but #2821 , that is almost never correct, which is why it is stupid to let empty files be created.)
c.f. coala/coala-bears#2414 (comment)
Also this will probably fix the regular problems we have with MarkdownBear.

issue.title: Path-settings for bears: Better support for relative files
issue.body:
From coala/coala-bears#2373 (by @cbaines):

If the rubocop config file is specified with a relative path, e.g. [1], then this means that coala must be run in a working directory such that the configuration file exists at this relative path. This breaks things like the Emacs Flycheck integration, which runs coala not always in the directory where the .coafile exists.
1:
rubocop_config = .rubocop.yml

issue.title: Result.py: Add docstring regarding the case that line or column is None
issue.body:
The output generated by coala can have line being None or column being None.
column = None means there is an error with the whole line.
line = None means the whole file. The reason behind it is that it's an unknown line means it can occur anywhere in the file.
All combinations with None values and numbers for line and column are allowed, except line=None and column=<some number>
This should be clarified in the documentation.
(ref: http://api.coala.io/en/latest/coalib.results.html#module-coalib.results.Result)

use_spaces = true

 Unable to convert parameter 'use_spaces' into type <class 'bool'>.

if your .coafile is
files = *.txt
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

bears = SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

No bears matching 'SpaceConsistencyBear

issue.title: Problems with nested `ignore` definitions in .coafile
issue.body:
Hi,
I have problem with ignore syntax in .coafile.
Check those 3 configurations:
# variant (1)

[all]
files = **/*.py
ignore =
    **/migrations/**,
    manage.py,
    wsgi.py,
    asgi.py,

[all.python.imports]
bears = PyImportSortBear


# variant (2)

[all]
files = **/*.py

[all.python.imports]
bears = PyImportSortBear
ignore =
    **/migrations/**,
    manage.py,
    wsgi.py,
    asgi.py,


# variant (3)

[all]
files = **/*.py
ignore =
    **/migrations/**,
    manage.py,

[all.python.imports]
bears = PyImportSortBear
ignore +=
    wsgi.py,
    asgi.py,

Variant (1) and (2) works as expected â€” files in migrations/ subdir and files wsgi.py + asgi.py are successfully ignored.
But when I try to split it like in variant (3) it doesnâ€™t work. Only wsgi.py + asgi.py are ignored, migrations/ are still checked by coala.
I also tried several variations of (3): rename section name to [all.imports], put ignore definitions on single line, include/exclude comma after last item, but all of them fails.
My env: coala version 0.11.0, run in Docker container.
Example of wrong output:

issue.title: Do integration testing with something like subprocess
issue.body:
I find current way of integration testing a bit hacky. In it we are relying a lot on the underlying structures (which makes it more of a unit testing of those structures than testing of the whole system from the user perspective), mocking stdout and stdin (which is prone to errors and complexities (for example with logging)).
I propose to do it more from the user perspective by using subprocess python module. This should also eliminate the need to mock std* and entry points, simplify dealing with logging and hopefully make tests cleaner.

issue.title: JSONFormatBear: Implement max_line_length with default 0
issue.body:
This is similar in nature to #1754
#2742 was a recent merge related to max line length for ipython files.
JSONFormatBear is a valid linter for ipython files, which are json with a different file extension and specific contents.   PEP8NotebookBear is the very specific linter for them, but JSONFormatBear is also useful.
Due to the fact json doesnt handle multi line strings, there is no sensible way to restrict the line length unless it is known that the contents will not use long lines, or should not contain long lines. e.g. if there are multiple ways of achieving something in the json, and the .coafile writer wants the people to only use inline for short strings and use a different approach for longer strings.  An artifical line length limit could also be used to prevent extremely deep nesting of objects.
Therefore, the only sensible default setting for max_line_length is 0.
However if someone knows the files only contains numbers and short fixed length strings, they can add a setting which overrides the default with a particular limit.
When implementing this error, it is very important that the bear doesnt try to fix the problem, because it is unfixable.  The solution is the user must increase the setting in .coafile, or they must redesign their use of json.  The error should say this.

issue.title: CPDBear deperately needs updating
issue.body:
Pertinent files:
research.zip
After messing around setting up a development environment for a absurdly long time, I was able to run CPDBear, and there are numerous problmes which I ran into:


CPDBear imports sub-libraries that don't exist in coalib (they likely once did exist, but not anymore)


CPDBear uses packages like PWD and bash instead of the python os package


CPDBear's language filtering cannot infer the language from a file type


CPDBear uses language filtering, even though it's a simple enough bear that it's functionality should be implemented without language-specific AST parsing(it should probably just warn of similar code greater than length n)


After debugging for a couple hours, the XML parsing broke entirely even though my code (provided in the .zip above) just passed the contents of files specified by --files into the parser


There is a language option which seems to be inaccessible through a command line switch, and rather you must type in the language directly into a CLI:
Please enter a value for the setting "language" (One of the supported languages of this bear.) needed by CPDBear for section "cli":


My recommendation is a complete overhaul or deletion of this file, and a investigation into if other example bears in general also use outdated or nonexistent imports.
If you want to replicate my results:
Get a cloned version from master of coala-bears as of 11/3/2018
Install necessary dependencies from pip(there seems to be a problem with colorama versioning as of 11/3/2018) , so this is a struggle in its own right.
Use setup.py install develop
Update coala-bears/bears/general/CPDBear.py with the CPDBear.py file provided in the zip above, and cd into the provided example directory, running coala --files py.js --bears CPDBear -V

issue.title: CommitBear: Check proper use of `https` when referencing issues for GitHub
issue.body:
https://github.com/coala/coala-bears/blob/master/bears/vcs/CommitBear.py#L360 matches links and tags, e.g. fix #123, fix https://github.com
This would also pass the test Closes http://github.com. However, this would not trigger GitHub autolinked reference feature. The commit message should be Closes https://github.com instead.
For those who are not familiar with autolinked reference feature, I did a simple experiment. I created an issue first li-boxuan/github-playground#1
Then I create a pr, aiming to close that issue. See commit message https://github.com/li-boxuan/github-playground/pull/2/commits. However, after this pr gets merged, it doesn't close the corresponding issue automatically.
Finally, this pr https://github.com/li-boxuan/github-playground/pull/3/commits closes the corresponding issue automatically when it's merged. Check commit messages carefully to see the difference.
That means we should check proper usage of https, at least for GitHub. Not sure if GitLab has similar features.

issue.title: CI fails due to autopep8 release of `1.4.1`
issue.body:
One of the changes that I figured out is related to the imports in which all imports(which is being imported below some code) is being moved to the beginning of the file.
e.g,
import os
import sys
import json

# Start ignoring PycodestyleBear* as those imports may raise
# import warnings
sys.path.append(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__),
                             '..', '..', '..', '..'))

from coalib.results.RESULT_SEVERITY import RESULT_SEVERITY
from coalib.output.JSONEncoder import create_json_encoder
from coalib.results.SourceRange import SourceRange
from coalib.results.Result import Result
is changed to
from coalib.results.RESULT_SEVERITY import RESULT_SEVERITY
from coalib.output.JSONEncoder import create_json_encoder
from coalib.results.SourceRange import SourceRange
from coalib.results.Result import Result
import os
import sys
import json

# Start ignoring PycodestyleBear* as those imports may raise
# import warnings
sys.path.append(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__),
                             '..', '..', '..', '..'))

Edit:
The autopep8 changes do not affect this bears repo but it is affecting the coala repo. An issue for that at coala/coala#5834.
It might require to take a look at PEP8Bear.py for the maintenance.

issue.title: Line continuation bear
issue.body:
Use of line continuation operators allows avoiding line length limitations without actually fixing the line length problem.  When it is used , the logical line is still very long, adding complexity, and now in addition the reader needs to understand an additional part of the syntax which often has unusual syntax/semantic/style rules of its own.
Ban it!
This will require coalang knows the token used for line continuation.
In many languages it is \ at the immediate end of the physical line, with only EOL chars \n & \r allows to follow it.

issue.title: Make writing bears simple again!
issue.body:
Most bears don't require a lot of Python code. Most of them can be declared as simple metadata.
I'm proposing giving developers a way to be able to write bears a lot simpler.
coala-bears is mostly metadata on how to run the linter, how to read it's output, what parameters to be thrown at it, etc.
We can simplify this by do one of the following options:

Write our own bear "language"
Use Moban

Package: coala

issue.title: JSONFormatBear: Message not appropriate when settings are omitted
issue.body:
This file can be reformatted by sorting keys and following indentation.

is always displayed, regardless whether you have actually enabled json_sort (to sort keys) or not. Especially it's displayed when you omit the setting altogether, and the default is actually false. So you think that the default is true.
The message has to be flexible for different parameters, so a user won't become confused.
Acceptance criteria:

The JSONFormatBear produces following messages for results in case that reformatting is possible:

When json_sort is False, the result message should be just This file can be reformatted by following indentation..
When json_sort is True, the result message should be like before (This file can be reformatted by sorting keys and following indentation.)

issue.title: Add NakedretBear

issue.title: Remove use of generic coverage pragma: no cover
issue.body:
# pragma: no cover avoids the requirement to test code.  It should be used extremely sparingly, and even when used for expediency, follow up patches should remove them.
$ git grep pragma
bears/__init__.py:def assert_supported_version():  # pragma: no cover
bears/__init__.py:    except ImportError:  # pragma: no cover
bears/c_languages/ClangBear.py:    except LibclangError as error:  # pragma: no cover
bears/c_languages/codeclone_detection/ClangCountingConditions.py:    return FOR_POSITION.UNKNOWN  # pragma: no cover
bears/c_languages/codeclone_detection/ClangCountingConditions.py:    return None  # pragma: no cover
bears/c_languages/codeclone_detection/ClangCountingConditions.py:            if operator is None:  # pragma: no cover
bears/elm/ElmLintBear.py:    def check_prerequisites(cls):  # pragma: no cover
bears/general/CPDBear.py:    def check_prerequisites(cls):  # pragma: no cover
bears/general/CPDBear.py:        if language not in self.lowered_lang_dict:  # pragma: no cover
bears/general/IndentationBear.py:    BEAR_DEPS = {AnnotationBear}  # pragma: no cover
bears/generate_package.py:if __name__ == '__main__':  # pragma: no cover
bears/java/JavaPMDBear.py:    def check_prerequisites(cls):  # pragma: no cover
bears/natural_language/AlexBear.py:        if parent_prereqs is not True:  # pragma: no cover
bears/natural_language/LanguageToolBear.py:            except ImportError:  # pragma: no cover
bears/python/requirements/PySafetyBear.py:            line_number, line = next(  # pragma: no branch
bears/vcs/git/GitCommitBear.py:        except LookupError as error:  # pragma: no cover
bears/vhdl/VHDLLintBear.py:    def check_prerequisites(cls):  # pragma: no cover

A lot of them seem to be in the check_prerequisites stage.
When doing this task , take only one bear and create a separate issue for it, linking back to this issue.

issue.title: ClangCountingConditions: macros should not destroy everything
issue.body:
_get_position_in_for_tokens contains # pragma: no cover with a scary FIXME:
"This is not covered in the tests because it contains a known bug that needs to be fixed, that is: macros destroy everything."
We need to add tests for macros (removing the # pragma; c.f. #1618), and ensure that they do not cause significant problems.
It is ok if they are not supported, but they should at least be silently discarded.
i.e. the behaviour with macros should be predictable, and not destructive.

issue.title: Proposal: Gitmate to submit patches when available from master builds
issue.body:
If coala dependencies update, new fixes may be automatically available.
They may come from new versions of linter tools, new releases of bears, or new data used by old bears.
The most common case for coala is updates to our mobans repo which need to be rolled out to all repos.
For this we will need a MobanBear .
The mechanism for creating PRs is simple, but will require some improvements to IGitt.
The logic for how to do this sanely in a constantly moving repo with humans involved is harder and needs a careful design and more careful implementation. We can and should do better than greenkeeper and similar.

issue.title: Update nested language proposal
issue.body:
The examples are confusing rather than helpful.
Php/HTML is a good example.
Another great example is reStructuredText, which allows specification of a language for a code block.  And Markdown now has a similar concept.  Our rstcheck bear already uses this and lints the code blocks.  Ideally this project would re-implement the rstcheck's linting of code blocks, so the splitting and spawning of linters is done inside coala instead of inside rstcheck, and the same functionality would be available for markdown without a custom bear.

issue.title: Project proposal: Improve the projects website for use by other GSoC orgs
issue.body:
https://projects.coala.io/ should be easily usable by other GSoC orgs, and potentially other GCI orgs by the end of this GCI.
However, the needs of other orgs hasnt been taken into account when build it.
A reasonable project proposal was put together in 2017, at #226 , but has been closed as the project hadnt finished being defined.  As this type of project will tend to be 'easy' by default, a significant amount of analysis of other orgs requirements should be done before proposing the idea, in order to find challenges that make this project significant enough for GSoC.

issue.title: semaphore CI scripts assume master branch is main repo
issue.body:
$ git grep master .ci/semaphore.*
.ci/semaphore.answers.sh:if [[ $BRANCH_NAME != "master" ]]
.ci/semaphore.docker.sh:if [[ $BRANCH_NAME == "master" ]]
Those assume that when BRANCH_NAME == "master", it is a push to the main repository.
It is quite common for people to accidentally build from the 'master' of forks, and submit PRs from that branch.
While it is highly undesirable that PRs come from master, and we intend to prevent it with a gitmate plugin, .ci/semaphore.docker.sh and .ci/semaphore.answers.sh should not break as a result.  They should detect pull requests, and not do the deploy-preparation steps.
c.f. #582 (comment) which broke because of this, and probably other PRs also.

issue.title: GCI Logo task
issue.body:
This 2017 GCI task was to create a new logo.

Before doing this task, you should have completed the "avatar" task,
This task involves designing a new logo for the coala bot, corobo.
Be creative and make your art aesthetically associated with corobo! You must be able to explain how your design relates to corobo. Interacte with corobo on gitter.im and Zulip. Let the bot inspire you!
You must submit a completely original design of your own creation that does not use 3rd party images from the web, unless they are licensed under Creative Commons licenses. If you create a design similar to something you found on the web, it is considered a derivative work and you should give proper attribution (i.e., credit) to that author by name with a link to their work. Failure to give credit is plagiarism and can be grounds for dismissal from GCI. When in doubt, design something unique. ;)
Logo design tips are in abundance around the web such as these 25 tips and these 7 tips.
Familiarity with a graphics design package like Gimp & Inkscape (open source & free), or Photoshop & Illustrator (not free) are useful for completing this task.
Upload your original vector artwork files to either https://www.behance.net/ or https://www.deviantart.com/ , with the same username as you have used for GitHub. Your uploaded files must be licensed under Creative Commons Sharealike. The winning design will be announced after all design entries have been assessed.

There were three completed, and we must select a winner.

Aryaman Singh : https://puppytron55.deviantart.com/art/Corobo-Te-Coala2-2-725271483



sagar gala : https://www.behance.net/gallery/60595919/logo-of-corobo



Abhay kumar: https://www.behance.net/gallery/60501641/corobo & https://www.deviantart.com/morelikethis/723888918

issue.title: Add status to issues tasks in tasks.yaml
issue.body:
When a task has max_instances: 1 and an issues URL , it can be annotated with an extra attribute to indicate the task status: available, claimed or completed.
Instance are exported as instances.yaml , and indicate whether the task is in progress or completed.
Completed issues are the easiest to work with.
In progress tasks are slightly more complicated because the publish instances are filtered to remove tasks still in early phases of the task lifecycle.  See https://github.com/coala/community/blob/master/gci/students.py#L84

issue.title: Use GraphQL API
issue.body:
We should use GitHub's GraphQL API instead of the the REST API. This will let us get a lot more data in many fewer requests.
You should preferably already have some GraphQL experience in order to properly make use of everything GraphQL has to offer, such as pagination and query variables.
Check out https://www.npmjs.com/package/graphql-client for making requests.

issue.title: Add configuration support
issue.body:
#1 is going to need to include configurability, so that repos with different structure can work in different ways.  i.e. we need to at least support @philschatz 's label system and derived gh-board layout, and support what @ryanprior likes, and what @coala needs, so that our patches will be able to make it back through the forks to the main repo (c.f. #2 )
There is one existing configuration item upstream, which is 'SAMPLE_REPOS' , and coala has added 'REPOSITORIES' for the pre-fetching.  I am surprised that there are no forks which have modified this (c.f. #5), as that seems like a logical easy way to improve the front page (c.f. #3).
Including configuration in the master branch causes forks to diverge.  We need to avoid that.
Some options for where to put the configuration:

the wiki
a different branch
an issue ;-)

Or, the configuration could be all derived from GitHub, if we ignore SAMPLE_REPOS. (and if we build a way to easily configure the front page, nobody will try to abuse this anyway.)  It will increase build time to extract an ideal layout based on GitHub org/repo metadata.  Also fetching the list of repos for an org requires an extra scope which orgs may not want in their Travis env vars, and if they use secure vars in the .travis.yml , their fork diverges.

issue.title: Login with invalid token doesnt have appropriate error message
issue.body:
When I put in an invalid token into the Login (like manually typing it on a mobile..), it doesnt show an appropriate error message.
Ideally the token is checked while the user is on the login form, and not saved if it doesnt work.
That allows better UI in the case of errors and avoids saving the token to be re-used on reload, etc

https://coala.io/#/coalaonline does not work due to the SOP security restrictions in browsers. This is bad for Coala marketing and therefore adoption!
# Chrome console:
Failed to load https://api.gitmate.io/coala_online/: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. Origin 'https://coala.io' is therefore not allowed access. The response had HTTP status code 504.

# Firefox console:
Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at https://api.gitmate.io/coala_online/. (Reason: CORS header 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' missing).

We can use CORS to get past these restrictions. (MDN, Wikipedia)
To do that, we must add some HTTP headers to the response provided from api.gitmate.io

comments.bodyText: Why is 3.4.3 not here?

it would slow down all builds, unnecessarily.
We could add it to master builds.
Or I think we can also only run jobs on the nightly cron, which would reduce delays if multiple PRs are getting merged.

What is the benefit of using moban to copy async.py from https://github.com/NAStools/homeassistant/blob/master/homeassistant/util/async.py? That project seems to be out of maintenance.
Drawbacks I can see:

licence is not stated in async.py, but in this file.
async.py needs to be excluded in .coafile.
async.py has other functions, e.g. fire_coroutine_threadsafe, which we don't use.
We cannot easily test it.

issue.title: Moban repo support
issue.body:
For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well

comments.bodyText:
The intention is to reduce the amount of change occurring in the tests, so that any functional changes are more obvious.  Any change to tests is a possible breakage.
The focus is on our docs and code which people read all the time.
The name of a variable in a test can be done as a newcomer issue later.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.

review your PRs faster!

@AkshJain99 - Yes, i'm trying to fix it.
I don't need squashing. I need to remove some commits which is something i'm working on. Thanks for the heads up.
Just a suggestion, before pushing your code, run coala locally on it and fix the errors ðŸ˜‰

It seems there are some changes in the master branch that are conflicting with my code. I'm not sure of if I should squash the last PR into the new one or not.
The only file I was hoping to keep is this one but it seems to be saying there is a merge conflict when I keep it: 71a315d
If someone can shed some light on what might be happening, i'm all ears.

Hiya @blossomica , yes, you have a merge conflict.  Someone else has also enhanced the same section of that file, but there changes are different.
We have some git help available at https://coala.io/git , and asking for help at https://coala.io/chat will usually mean you get someone who will step you through the process of resolving a merge conflict.
Worst case, as a maintainer , I can remotely fix the merge conflict in the PR for you.  But ideally you try to solve it first.
What is not an acceptable, is starting a new Pull Request.

@jayvdb - Thanks for the clarification. It makes sense. I had no idea someone was working on the same file. But my biggest confusion (which I'll ask on gitter too) is this: when I fix the merge conflict and select "merge commit" for some reason it changes and commits more files than what I thought was changed. Like more than the file that had the merge conflict in, so I'm not sure if that is the supposed response or not, which makes me hesitant to squash that into my main commit.

@blossomica Try doing this:


Rebase the changes on your local machine which would result in some merge conflict.


Try resolving them on your local machine.


After the conflict has been resolved, try running coala locally on your machine so as to find the errors.


Once done with it, commit the changes and you are GTG


If there's an additional commit after resolving conflict, you can  squash it using git rebase -i , also known as interactive rebase.


I think this should work fine ðŸ˜„
@jayvdb  - I added the notice you suggested about the short log where fix is used but isn't an actual bug fix. So please check if that is okay too whenever you can.

issue.title: Add Brackets editor Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.
Closes #5829

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!

them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review

comments.bodyText:
I think that may be a heavily modified version of TinyBasic designed specifically for programming micro controllers. TinyBasic seems to have been written in the 1970s (see this guide from 1976), and the guide that you linked to is from 2009. Wikipedia seems to corroborate the 1970s timeline, and it doesn't refer to any recently updated version of TinyBasic.
In addition to that, the creator of TinyBasic according to Wikipedia is Dennis Allison (from the US), while the creator of the TinyBasic from the guide that you linked is Dr.-Ing. (from Germany). The sample code published on that guide's site also does not seem to match in style to samples provided in this original guide.

Five things:

assert not timeout should be removed now. That is the main aim of the issue.
It would be incorrect to use warnings.warn here. We should use logging.warning when the event is to be noted, and the end user cannot do anything about it. (Source: Python Docs)
The message ought to be more verbose
A test would be nice. We're merely 6 lines away from reaching 100% branch coverage. (This is what caused my delay ðŸ˜› )
Should be Closes instead of Fixes. #5812 isn't a bug, but rather an issue.
So should I proceed further with the changes or are you submitiing your PR?
@aquatiko I'm not sure about that. More discussion is required, switch to gitter.
@mach64 Could you explain what should be included in the test that you mentioned?

@aquatiko have a look at the files in tests/testing/. You should basically have a test to check that when the verfiy_local_bear function is called with the timeout parameter, a warning is generated. If you get stuck, go through the other files in the folder to see how to properly test strings being printed to stdout and stderr.

In addition, before committing your changes, it is absolutely necessary to run coala on your modified codebase. This will ensure that your changes are fully PEP-8 compliant. (Currently, after every push, you can see that the gitmate bot complains about some inconsistencies. Better to solve them locally, before committing).

@mach64 Added if timeout: to log warning only when timeout occurs. Wouldn't that comply with the changes requested? i.e in the latest commit

@aquatiko Moving on, did you have a look at the testing code under tests/testing, and try to add a new test? What part are you getting stuck at?

issue.title: collecting: Fix incorrect trailing '**' warning
issue.body:
The warning is necessary only when the rest of the ignore path is a
canonical directory which doesn't contain any wildcards. This commit
adds a check to ensure that if the path contains other wildcards, the
warning isn't generated.

issue.title: coalaTest: Add test preventing unknown warnings
issue.body:
Currently the test_coala_with_color and _without_color
tests fail with little indication of what is happening,
especially as the first warnings messages are related to
the .coafile 'Default' section.  The reported error is
trimmed, preventing the real cause of the error from
being seen in the logs.  It can be hiding a backtrace.
This introduces a new test which explicitly checks for
the two types of warnings which are currently happening,
being the 'Default' section and missing bears warnings.
These are happening because the repository .coafile is
being loaded instead of only using CLI arguments.
Then any additional warnings are considered to be an
error, and the entire output is show, so the reader
can see what is causing the problem.
Related to #5390

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review

issue.title: Addition of Visual Studio Code to the list of known editors
issue.body:
Issue in focus: #5150
Added VSCode to the list of known GUI Editors.
Clarifications:

VSCode is has it's path linked to variable code, hence the name code. This is true for Windows, MacOS and Linux(Arch Linux, Ubuntu and Linux Mint are tested upon) and is evident from their documentation on Windows and macOS

There is an internal command too, to set the path variable specifiaclly to code as can be seen from this gif:

Guidance Required:

There exists a way to open a file to a particular line and position in VSCode but doesn't follow the scheme like the rest of the editors. In order to open a file to a particular location, the command goes:
$code <file_name>:{line}:{column} -g. Here the -g is mandatory. If -g is failed to be specified, a new file with peculiar extension is opened.
For Ex: .j:8:9 would be the extension of the file.
This is even specified in their docs found here
So the question arises should the -g be put as an args or should it be included in the file opening scheme itself.

Desription of args parameters:

-g - Goto a specific line
-n - Open new window
r - Reuse current window
--wait - Wait for the file to be closed before returning.

Any changes required will be implemented as soon as possible.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
It sounds like {filename}:{line}:{column} --goto will work .. ?
I think that is the best approach, because then it is obvious that --goto is the special sauce for getting the file template to work, and --goto would then be omitted if the editor is being opened without a filename. (I'm sure we do not use it like that, but we could in the future ... ;-) )

could we use long args for these ?
maybe a bit less fragile, and much more readable what the editor supports.

Sometimes, though, it is "required" to have a PR closed, when a maintainer asks you to. "Allowed" is a viable option, but it proposes a rather radical tonality. "Accepted" would be another option...What do you think?

issue.title: Setting.py: Add SourcePosition to Setting.origin
issue.body:
This adds SourcePosition to Setting.origin which helps
in identifying the starting line number of a setting in
.coafile.
Related to #5044

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
Rather than add a new argument, re-use origin, and let it be given either a str (filename / directory; backwards compatibility) or a SourcePosition.
There is very little use of self.origin within the class or superclasses - those uses will need to be adjusted to get the filename out of the SourcePosition when it is a filename.
The attribute Setting.origin needs to externally able to be automatically converted to a string, so str(Setting.origin) needs to work correctly.  One way to do that is for  str(SourcePosition) to be implemented.
After this initial PR, we can then also enhance ConfParser and allow Setting.origin to be given as a SourceRange to identify the precise start and end of each settings.  But that is later.  (You could do that in this PR if you wanted, but only it is easy to do.  Otherwise it is better to do this in stages.)
Then the real fun begins when we consider section inheritance and +=, and even more funky when we consider #5532 .  To model that correctly we would need a new class for "MultipleRanges", which would probably become a superclass for the Diff class which we do have.

issue.title: ConfParser.py: Support multiple +=
issue.body:
This ensures that multiple instances
of += can be used in single settings
section.
Fixes #5532

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Newcomers_Guide.rst: Explain newcomer issues
issue.body: (This is a bit raw and rough and aggressive.  Need help to tone it down a bit, while still being effective at being a challenge to newcomers, and adequately warning them that we dont care about their "one line change" -- it is going to be rejected if they dont comply with the guidelines.)

comments.bodyText: typo in workflow and accommodate.

+The coala organisation tries to have ``newcomer`` issues always available
+for people who are joining the organisation.  These newcomer issues are
+intentionally very easy.  The only objective is to give you, the newcomer,

comments.bodyText:
This implies that people who don't follow the coala workflow are reluctant to learn ...

Correct. ;-)
We have too many drive by PRs, especially from people who attended "code sprints" or other similar workshops, who don't approach their first PR with the right mentality, and lack the self-motivation to complete it.
I hope this new blurb can shock/challenge the reader a bit, without scaring off too many.
By informing the reader in advance that a PR will not be auto-merged, it hopefully makes them more ready to see a PR as a process which might take some time, and we dont want them to start it unless they are ready to finish it.
We definitely dont want PRs from people who are not interested in learning about 'git' , etc.
Getting your first patch merged into a repository almost always requires learning, even if the change is very basic.
We should be up-front about this, not try to hide behind an overly welcoming sign on the front door, and then kick them around once they have come in the door.  The sign on the front door should say "You will get kicked around if you don't want to learn."  Nicely.

for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!

them.

individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,

comments.bodyText:
Yeah, so the point of aliases in this file is not to focus on the features of ANTLR's jar, the point of aliases in this file is to focus on language specific features of the grammar files, of which grun is not a part.
aliases are supposed to refer to things that mean the same as g4. For example aliases of jpeg format would be jpeg / jpg, but not Inkscape or Photoshop.
Also please not that grun is not any officially endorsed thing, it's just a bash shell alias (similar to ll which is given to org.antlr.v4.gui.TestRig for convenience sake, it could very well be any arbitrary name which we want.

issue.title: Add Brackets editor Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.
Closes #5829

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: alpha order please
@jayvdb I checked, brackets does not support jumping to a line number.
@amalrajan @utkarsh2102  thank you very much for the solution .

and the issue is still pending review , what should i do create new pull request or wait ?
@jayvdb  please guide

Never close a Pull Request. You need to learn how to fix them.
First step is to squash your 5 commits, which you can see at https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/5831/commits ,  into a single commit.
The easiest way to do that, is to delete the top 4 commits, erasing your incorrect extra commits.
To do that, you find the identifier of the first commit in your series, which was 68b6cf0 , and reset to that position.
git reset --hard 68b6cf080b
Then edit the file again, but make sure you amend your first commit, instead of creating new commits.
git add coalib/results/result_actions/OpenEditorAction.py
git commit --amend

Squash 5 commits into 1 locally and then push them to your fork,you can look onto the following link for it
https://github.com/todotxt/todo.txt-android/wiki/Squash-All-Commits-Related-to-a-Single-Issue-into-a-Single-Commit
Follow the guidelines given in https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Writing_Good_Commits.html to write the commit message properly and you are good to go..

issue.title: Add Brackets editor Code to known editors for coala
issue.body:
Added bracket to the list of known GUI Editors.
Guidance Required:
In order to open a file , the command goes:
Open a file in the current folder,
without switching projects:
brackets index.html
Open two files from a specific path,
without switching projects:
brackets ~/Sites/index.html ~/Sites/index.css
Open the current folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets .
Open a specific folder as a project in Brackets:
brackets ~/Sites/mysite
Brackets can be launched from the command line.
Presently it does not accept any other arguments.
Any updates required will be implemented.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review

issue.title: coalib: FileDict and FileFactory compatibility fixes
issue.body:
__len__ and __getitem__ are missing magic methods of
dict needed to be emulated in order to be backwards compatible.
These are needed by coala-quickstart green mode to work on master.
Closes #5810

comments.bodyText:
IMHO The above approach wouldn't work because len(section.contents) would never be zero.
The reason being section.contents is never empty. Even if your .coafile is something like below where your [cli] section is not present. It would help you to know that the [ cli ] section is generated automatically by Cliparser.py when you supply the arguments to coala. This section gets saved to your .coafile when you supply --save option.
[python]
files = admin.py
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear, QuotesBear
language = Python
preferred_quotation = '

default_actions = **: ApplyPatchAction

When i tried to debug it, section.contents always returns a Ordered dict of length 1 when the contents in the [ cli ] section is empty. I tried to print the value of section.contents when the [ cli ] section is empty. It's something like:-
OrderedDict([('comment0', <Setting object(key='comment0', value='', origin='/home/theprophet/git/thepursuit/oth/.coafile', from_cli=False, to_append=False) at 0x7f5ed01aa1d0>)])


From the above result I can positively say that section always maintains elements in its dictionary even when a section is empty.This is done so that the core of coala can properly identify it.
That's the reason, you checking if len(section.contents) == 0 will not work.Since this doesn't work your if condition fails and the message Executing Section CLI will always prompt up.
I guess you need to change your approach.
P.S:- Please test your changes locally before creating a PR. This will save yours and the reviewers time :)
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -183,7 +183,8 @@ def run_coala(console_printer=None,
                 section['default_actions'] = '*: ShowPatchAction'
                 section['show_result_on_top'] = 'yeah'
 
-            print_section_beginning(section)
+            if not (section.name == 'cli' and len(section.contents) == 0):

comments.bodyText:
IMO you are editing the wrong file.
I don't think we usually have a [ cli ] section in our .coafile. I rarely used a [ cli ] section on my projects. I might be as well be wrong here ðŸ˜… . Better confirm it.
In any case, I guess this issue has two parts:-


Print Executing Section CLI only when the coala is provided with options. eg:-
coala --file = avenger.py --bears SpaceConsistencyBear, print the message Executing Section CLI when you execute this. But do not print it when you do the same operation using a .coafile.
Executing section cli gets printed even when we supply no arguments to coala.
If there was no [ cli ] section in the .coafile then this could be solved by a very small change in your present solution.


Check if there is a section named [ cli ] in the .coafile and check if its contents are empty (Do not use section.contents ðŸ˜…). If so do not print the message. If it isn't empty then print it. But then again, this is a kinda broader issue.


I mean if we are checking if the section [ cli ] is empty and then avoid printing the message Executing section cli if it is. Shouldn't we avoid printing the section beginning message  for all the sections that have no content in them in the .coafile. I don't know if that's the scope of the issue. If that is then I think it should be tackled in another issue of its own. @ishanSrt need your opinion on this. Is this covered in the scope of the current issue?

please always retain the style that you find in a file, if it is consistent.  The maintainers of that file probably like the style they have chosen, and wont appreciate it changing for not reason.

Changing it to the current year since application period for 2019 projects are between May-Aug 2019.
That wont be correct either, it should point to next year Sept onwards. Try fetching the month and do your voodoo :)

issue.title: application-template.md: Make GSoC application template dynamic
issue.body:
Have the year on the GSoC application template on the FAQ page change based on the month. If it's past September, the page will show the next year, otherwise it will show the current year.
Closes #671

But, you created extra work for yourself ;-)
Now you have added a constant , and constants should go into
https://github.com/coala/projects/blob/master/_config.yml
GSOC_SWITCH_MONTH: 7
lower_case key names in that global file is also ok.
or maybe even June?
(September is a bit too late -- we get questions much earlier)

issue.title: projects.html: Added GSoC project reports link
issue.body:
The following commit adds a link of past years GSoC project reports in projects.html, just below the project ideas link under the search bar.
Fixes #683

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: renamed to next year, NOT a number
issue.body:
Closes #672

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.body:
The proposal is updated for handling nested
language which is one of the Gsoc projects
to understand the concept of handling nested
language more better.
Closes #547

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: coala-will-apply-for-gsoc-2018.md: Remove references to specific years
issue.body:
Closes #672

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

[*] I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
[*] I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Remove report_year from report layout
issue.body:
For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

This PR removes the report_year property from the report layout, and instead uses the date property to determine the year of the report. All report markdown files (including the template) have been edited to remove the redundant property.
Closes #669

likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

instead.

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

Hi @Dhiraj240, thanks for the PR! Check out this link to learn more about proper commit format (improper commit format will cause the builds to fail). Also, make sure to squash your commits into one!

@Dhiraj240 if you scroll to the bottom of the Travis message, it provides some helpful hints on how to fix any problems. In this case:
**** GitCommitBear [Section: commit | Severity: NORMAL] ****
!    ! Shortlog of HEAD commit isn't in imperative mood! Bad words are 'Added'

You should be using the imperative tense in your commit message (documented here), so say Add StackOverflow tag instead of Added StackOverflow tag. This is the typical format for a Git commit message.

issue.title: ci: Add repository check to semaphore scripts
issue.body: Fixes #583

comments.bodyText:
Currently this does run in "coala/corobo" PRS on the semaphore CI, so this logic isnt quite right, as it would prevent this from running on PRs.
I think this one (.ci/check_docker.py; pull_and_build) can be done on forks, so the extra condition isnt necessary.

The second one was not breaking the build. It was supoosed to be run only when the branch is master. So I assumed it was the case of direct push and hence it should be coala/corobo. Also not being the master branch means it's a PR and not coala/corobo that's why I put the condition there.
Also I think check_docker.py and pull_and_build will still run if it a fork rather now it will only run if its a fork.

The issue is about "deploy-preparation steps".  The task is to prevent build breakages which are occurring.
.ci/check_docker.py & pull_and_build do not causes breakages.  They are not being run on master because it is assumed that the tests have already been run on the PR.  If it is in master, it was tested already.  So it doesnt need to be done again.
docker push creates breakages, because random forkers and PRs dont have permission to push to that docker image name.  That is the problem which needs fixing.
Yes even when I made changes it didnt break the build. I have donr the changes now. Please see again.

issue.title: requirements.txt: Bump IGitt dependency
issue.body:
Use latest IGitt, and also include a commit which
unpins package cryptography so it is easier to
install IGitt, otherwise the old version required of
cryptography may require the user has a compiler
set up, as wheels may not work on their system.

issue.title: GCI: Add fetch_linter_issues command
issue.body:
Usage:
GH_TOKEN=YOUR_TOKEN python manage.py fetch_sub_linter_issues ./foo/bar/repos.txt

parser.add_argument('--labels', '-l', nargs='*')
parser.add_argument('--keywords', '-k', nargs='*')
parser.add_argument('--threads', '-t', type=int)
parser.add_argument('--all', action='store_true')
If labels or keywords are not passed, a default set will be used. To get a list of all issues use --all. Primary repo list https://gist.github.com/ksdme/fcc26083fe7aae4b8e314892ca302718

@@ -0,0 +1,93 @@
+import re
+from multiprocessing import Pool
+
+from IGitt.GitHub.GitHub import GitHub, GitHubToken
+
+re_gh = r'https?://github\.com'
+re_gh_repo = r'https?://github\.com/([\w-]+/[\w-]+)'
+
+
+def get_github(token):
+    return GitHub(GitHubToken(token))
+
+
+def get_repo_host(url):
+    if re.match(re_gh, url):
+        return 'github'
+
+
+def get_repo_name(url, host):
+    if host == 'github':
+        result = re.match(re_gh_repo, url)
+        return result and result.groups()[0]
+
+
+def simplify_issue(issue, repo_url=''):
+    return {
+      'id': issue.number,
+      'repo_url': repo_url,
+      'title': issue.title,
+      'labels': list(issue.labels),
+      'description': issue.description,
+    }
+
+
+def _lower_set(iterable):
+    return set(map(str.lower, iterable))
+
+
+def issue_filter(issue, labels, desc_keywords):
+    norm_issue_labels = _lower_set(issue['labels'])
+    norm_labels = _lower_set(labels)
+
+    if len(norm_issue_labels & norm_labels) > 0:
+        return True
+
+    norm_keywords = _lower_set(desc_keywords)
+    norm_text = str.lower(issue['title'] + ' ' + issue['description'])
+    norm_text = set(norm_text.split())
+
+    if len(norm_keywords & norm_text) > 0:
+        return True
+
+
+def fetch_issues(hosts, targets, labels=[],
+                 desc_keywords=[], threads=8, debug=False):
+
+    all_repo_issues = {}
+    github = hosts.get('github')
+
+    for target in targets:
+        if debug:
+            print('processing', target)
+
+        try:
+            host = get_repo_host(target)
+
+            if host == 'github':
+                gh_repo_name = get_repo_name(target, host)
+                gh_repo = github.get_repo(gh_repo_name)

+
+    norm_keywords = _lower_set(desc_keywords)
+    norm_text = str.lower(issue['title'] + ' ' + issue['description'])

comments.bodyText:
Sometimes I encounter the issue  (node:1599) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): TypeError: Cannot read property 'line' of undefined. See https://app.netlify.com/sites/gci-leaders/deploys/5bd2b2ddb13fb157f7a0a066
Probably an upstream bug with graphql-client. Retry sometimes solves the problem.
UPDATE:
So from my experiment and observation, it is a bug with upstream project graphql-client.
https://github.com/nordsimon/graphql-client/blob/f8d1dcba8a65f290e35b71c883a18094594d6d5a/index.js#L2
can lead to an error when elements in errors array don't have locations field.
However, GitHub is supposed to include the locations field when returning errors.
For example, a normal errors should be sth like this:
[{"message":"Could not resolve to an Organization with the login of 'GCI-AOSSIE'.","type":"NOT_FOUND","path":["organization"],"locations":[{"line":2,"column":3}]}]
However, sometimes GitHub returns this:
[{"message":"Something went wrong while executing your query. This may be the result of a timeout, or it could be a GitHub bug. Please include `E689:1AF6:67E816:BAAF4C:5BD321E1` when reporting this issue."}]
which causes the error of graphql-client.
CONCLUSION: a bug of upstream project graphql-client. It only happens occasionally, coz it's caused due to some unknown error of GitHub.

Created an issue #163

could you re-arrange the logging so that earliestDate is always put into the log, i.e. add a log entry after this block of code -- before const ignoreAuthor...
Then there is always a record of what data set should be found in the deploy.
Here in this log entry, the output is quite strange.   For this deploy, which doesnt have EARLIEST_DATE or EARLIEST_DATE_PR set, it is:

To speed up netlify pr build, set earliest date threshold 2018-08-01T05:19:50+00:00

That log entry sounds like we should set the earliest date threshold to that date, yet .. that is the automatic date now, so it would be useless to set it at that date.
We would need to set it at a more recent date , if we wanted less data to be processed.
So the log message here needs rewriting now to complement the revised logic.
It is more useful to log the value of EARLIEST_DATE and EARLIEST_DATE_PR , and the final selected earliest date.  Then it is a fairly simple logical deduction that setting EARLIEST_DATE and EARLIEST_DATE_PR may be useful to override the automatically computed default.

I do not see the value in this restriction, especially not now with automatic sensible defaults earliest dates for PRs.
Due to your change, the only way this condition can be false is when an admin of the Netlify control panel sets EARLIEST_DATE_PR to be earlier than EARLIEST_DATE , which is silly.  But if they really want to do that, we should respect that ... maybe they are doing stress testing or something like that.
I'm sorry I didn't really get what's to be done here. Can you please brief me a little more?

I understand that the if condition is always going to be false unless an admin of the Netlify control panel sets EARLIEST_DATE_PR to be earlier than EARLIEST_DATE.

issue.title: .coafile: Update .coafile to new format
issue.body:
Closes #148

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: Make copyright year dynamic in coala.io
issue.body:
This entrypoint ensures copyright year in foot of coala.io updates every
year automatically.
This helps in not updating the same every year.
Closes #290

comments.bodyText:
Can someone clarify why it is showing this PR has issues?
I have removed all the trailing white spaces.

Can't really help with the whitespace problem, but I think that the code in itself is not working. If i try your exact solution, my whole page gets overwritten and only the new Date is being displayed. However in the following solution everything works fine: © coala Maybe try that.

@Tyroc Thnx for your suggestion. But your code is producing same output as mine in my machine. I have just changed the year part of the code. Rest html page is still the same.  I don't know why your whole page is being overwritten with my code. Please correct me if I am wrong anywhere. Thnx once again.
@Vaibhav911 Then there must be a problem with my machine. Sorry! Good contribution btw.

@Tyroc, I guess you were right.  if I run document.write after the document has loaded ,it overwrite the whole page. If it is run before that, it does not overwrite it. So I am using a little different approach now. Thank you so much for pointing out my mistake. I will correct it soon.
Run coala on your code locally before making a push.
Sorry, I will take care of this from next time. Now I have tested the code completely and it's working fine. I am about to squash it.

issue.title: Make code examples on homepage bookmarkable
issue.body:
Add lang parameter to the URL
Fixes #277

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!
